samples.prompt:
You are a creative writing assistant.
Write a short horror story that follows this story specification.

Title: The Mirror in the Attic
Setting: a school after everyone has gone home
Protagonist: Mina
Supporting character: Sora
Important object: a child's drawing
Taboo rule: never say the missing person's name out loud
Twist: the secondary character has been repeating the same day

Constraints:
- 2 to 4 paragraphs.
- Keep it suspenseful and eerie, not graphic.
- End with an unsettling implication.

Story:

Twist: the secondary character has been repeating the same day

Constraints:
- 2 to 4 paragraphs.
- Keep it suspenseful and eerie, not graphic.
- End with an unsettling implication.

Story:
Mina only meant to help Sora, but the rule was clear: never say the missing person's name out loud.

 bus stop at midnight, Mina found a child's drawing and wished they hadn't.

Somewhere nearby, a soft scraping answered every silence, like a patient listener practicing a name. The air felt thinner each time a child's drawing changed hands, as if it was counting something no one could see. Then it happened: the secondary character has been repeating the same day.

In the mirror-dark, Mina saw Sora behind them—except Sora was still speaking from the other side of the door.<|endoftext|> insisted it was still speaking from the other side of the door.<|endoftext|> heard a knock from inside the room, slow and grateful.<|endoftext|>

samples.prompt:
You are a creative writing assistant.
Write a short horror story that follows this story specification.

Title: The Last Candle
Setting: a rural bus stop at midnight
Protagonist: Iris
Supporting character: Theo
Important object: a child's drawing
Taboo rule: never say the missing person's name out loud
Twist: the protagonist has been the missing person all along

Constraints:
- 2 to 4 paragraphs.
- Keep it suspenseful and eerie, not graphic.
- End with an unsettling implication.

Title: The Last Candle
Setting: a rural bus stop at midnight
Protagonist: Iris
Supporting character: Theo
Important object: a child's drawing
Taboo rule: never say the missing person's name out loud
Twist: the protagonist has been the missing person all along

Constraints:
- 2 to 4 paragraphs.
- Keep it suspenseful and eerie, not graphic.
- End with an unsettling implication.

Story:
In a rural bus stop at midnight, Iris found a child's drawing and wished they hadn't.

The air felt thinner each time a child's drawing changed hands, as if it was counting something no one could see. Somewhere nearby, a soft scraping answered every silence, like a patient listener practicing a name. Only when the lights failed did the truth land—the protagonist has been the missing person all along.

When Iris tried to leave, the hallway stretched and the a child's drawing grew warm in their pocket, as if it had finally found its owner.<|endoftext|> wrapped in the last candle and heard a knock from inside the room, slow and grateful.<|endoftext|> blew out the last candle and heard a knock from inside the room, slow and grateful.<|endoftext|> blew out the last candle
